intro: Heracleum austriacum var. elegans, commonly known as the Austrian cow parsnip, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is native to Central Europe. It is a biennial plant that typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring a hollow, ridged stem and large, pinnately divided leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, greenish-yellow flowers in umbrella-like inflorescences, which are characteristic of the carrot family. Its leaves and stems are covered with fine hairs, and it has a distinct, aromatic odor when crushed. The plant is often found in moist meadows, stream banks, and woodland edges, where it thrives in partial to full sunlight.
